title: Frida's Journey
subtitle: Follow the iconic Mexican artist from Casa Azul to the world
introduction: Frida Kahlo lived an extraordinary life marked by physical suffering, passionate love, and artistic genius. Born and died in the same house in Coyoacán, she transformed personal pain into universal art. Her self-portraits explored identity, gender, and Mexican heritage with unflinching honesty. Today, Casa Azul remains the essential pilgrimage for understanding this revolutionary artist.

trail.shortDescription: Where Frida was born, lived, and died
trail.description: Frida was born in the Casa Azul (Blue House) on July 6, 1907, though she later claimed 1910 to align with the Mexican Revolution. She lived here as a child, returned after her marriage to Diego Rivera, and spent her final years in its colorful rooms. The house became her universe, especially after her health confined her to bed.
trail.significance: The Casa Azul is Frida's soul made visible. Every room, every object tells her story. This is where she created most of her 200 paintings and where she died in 1954.

whatToSee.name: Museo Frida Kahlo (Casa Azul)
whatToSee.description: Frida's birthplace and home, preserved exactly as she left it. Contains her paintings, Diego's art, pre-Columbian artifacts, and her wheelchair and medical corsets.
whatToSee.note: Book tickets online well in advance. The house is small and limits daily visitors.

whatToSee.name: Frida's Garden
whatToSee.description: The lush courtyard garden where Frida kept monkeys, parrots, and hairless dogs. The pyramid-shaped structure houses Diego's pre-Columbian collection.

whatToSee.name: Frida's Studio
whatToSee.description: Her wheelchair positioned at the easel, mirrors she used for self-portraits, and the bed where she painted during illness.

whatToSee.name: Coyoacán Centro
whatToSee.description: The charming colonial neighborhood Frida loved, with plazas, markets, and cafes. Walk the streets she walked.

trail.shortDescription: Where teenage Frida met Diego Rivera
trail.description: At 15, Frida enrolled at the prestigious Escuela Nacional Preparatoria, one of only 35 girls among 2,000 students. Here she joined a rebellious group called 'Los Cachuchas' and first saw Diego Rivera painting his mural Creation. She reportedly declared she would have his baby. In 1925, a bus accident shattered her body and changed her life forever.
trail.significance: The Preparatoria shaped Frida's intellectual life and introduced her to Diego. The 1925 accident, which broke her spine in three places, led directly to her art. She began painting during her long recovery.

whatToSee.name: Antiguo Colegio de San Ildefonso
whatToSee.description: The former Preparatoria school, now a museum. See Diego's first mural and the amphitheater where he worked while teenage Frida watched.

whatToSee.name: Secretaría de Educación Pública
whatToSee.description: Diego's monumental mural cycle covering 1,585 square meters. Free entry to see where he worked while courting Frida.

whatToSee.name: Palacio de Bellas Artes
whatToSee.description: Houses Frida works alongside murals by Diego, Orozco, and Siqueiros

trail.description: Frida first came to San Francisco as Diego's wife while he painted murals. Here she met Dr. Leo Eloesser, who became her lifelong medical advisor. She painted her first major self-portrait as an artist in her own right, declaring her Mexican identity against American culture. She returned in 1940 for medical treatment and remarried Diego here.
trail.significance: San Francisco transformed Frida from Diego's wife into an independent artist. Her portrait of the city versus Mexico shows her growing political consciousness.

whatToSee.name: San Francisco Art Institute
whatToSee.description: Where Diego painted his mural The Making of a Fresco. Frida appears in it.

whatToSee.name: SFMOMA
whatToSee.description: Houses Frida's painting Frieda and Diego Rivera (1931)

whatToSee.name: City Hall
whatToSee.description: Where Frida and Diego remarried on December 8, 1940

trail.description: While Diego painted his famous Detroit Industry murals, Frida experienced devastating loss. She suffered a miscarriage at Henry Ford Hospital, leading to one of her most powerful paintings. Her hatred of industrial America and longing for Mexico intensified. The emotional turmoil produced breakthrough works that established her distinct artistic voice.
trail.significance: Detroit broke Frida's heart and made her an artist. Henry Ford Hospital and Self-Portrait on the Border Line emerged from this painful year, marking her artistic maturity.

whatToSee.name: Detroit Institute of Arts
whatToSee.description: Houses Diego's Detroit Industry murals in the Garden Court. The museum where Frida spent countless hours while Diego worked.

whatToSee.name: The Wardell (Former residence)
whatToSee.description: The apartment building where Frida and Diego lived during their Detroit stay

trail.description: André Breton invited Frida to Paris for an exhibition of her work. The Surrealists claimed her as one of their own, but she rejected the label, famously saying 'I never painted dreams. I painted my own reality.' The Louvre purchased The Frame, making her the first Mexican artist in their collection. Despite artistic success, she hated Paris.
trail.significance: Paris validated Frida internationally but she refused to be categorized. The Louvre acquisition was historic. Picasso gave her earrings; she gave Breton her honest disdain for Surrealism.

whatToSee.name: Centre Pompidou
whatToSee.description: Houses The Frame, the self-portrait the Louvre purchased in 1939

whatToSee.name: Galerie Renou et Colle (Former location)
whatToSee.description: Where Frida's 1939 exhibition Mexique was held

whatToSee.name: Saint-Germain-des-Prés
whatToSee.description: The neighborhood where Frida met Surrealists at cafes like Les Deux Magots

currentLocations.title: Where to See Frida's Work Today
currentLocations.description: Frida created only about 200 paintings, making each one precious. Here are the essential collections:

topMuseums.name: Museo Frida Kahlo (Casa Azul)
topMuseums.note: Her birthplace and home, the essential Frida experience

topMuseums.name: Museo Dolores Olmedo
topMuseums.note: The largest Frida collection, plus Diego works

topMuseums.name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
Centre Pompidou
topMuseums.note: The Frame, first Mexican work in the Louvre collection

suggestedItineraries.name: Casa Azul Day
suggestedItineraries.description: Immerse yourself in Frida's world at Casa Azul and explore Coyoacán's charming streets

suggestedItineraries.name: Frida's Mexico City
suggestedItineraries.description: Casa Azul, the murals Diego painted for her, and the Dolores Olmedo collection

suggestedItineraries.name: California Frida
suggestedItineraries.description: San Francisco and the Bay Area's Frida connections

suggestedItineraries.name: The Complete Frida
suggestedItineraries.description: From Mexico City to San Francisco to Paris, following Frida's international journey

timeline.event: Born in Coyoacán, Mexico City on July 6
Enrolls at the Preparatoria; first sees Diego Rivera
Bus accident breaks her spine, pelvis, and leg
First trip to San Francisco with Diego
Miscarriage in Detroit; paints Henry Ford Hospital
Paris exhibition; Louvre purchases The Frame; divorces Diego
First solo exhibition in Mexico; attends in her bed
Dies at Casa Azul on July 13, aged 47
